article:
2022 Malaysian General Election

The 2022 Malaysian general election was the 15th general election in Malaysia, held on 19 November 2022. The election was called following the dissolution of the 14th Malaysian Parliament on 10 October 2022. The election saw the participation of 945 candidates from various political parties and coalitions, contesting for 222 parliamentary seats and 600 state legislative seats.

# Background

## Previous Election

The 14th Malaysian general election was held on 9 May 2018, which saw the Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition, led by Mahathir Mohamad, winning a majority of 113 seats in the Dewan Rakyat, the lower house of the Malaysian Parliament. The Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition, which had ruled Malaysia since independence in 1957, suffered a major defeat, winning only 79 seats.

## Significant Events

Several significant events took place in the lead-up to the 2022 general election. In February 2020, the Pakatan Harapan government, led by Mahathir Mohamad, collapsed following a series of defections by several Members of Parliament (MPs). This led to the formation of a new government, led by Muhyiddin Yassin, which was supported by the BN coalition and several other parties.

In January 2021, a state of emergency was declared in Malaysia due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to the suspension of parliamentary activities. The emergency was lifted in August 2021, following which the 14th Malaysian Parliament reconvened.

## 2020–22 Political Crisis

The period between 2020 and 2022 saw a series of political crises in Malaysia. In February 2020, the Pakatan Harapan government collapsed, leading to the formation of a new government. In July 2021, the Prime Minister, Muhyiddin Yassin, faced a confidence vote in parliament, which he won narrowly.

However, in August 2021, the Prime Minister resigned following a series of defections by several MPs. He was replaced by Ismail Sabri Yaakob, who formed a new government with the support of the BN coalition and several other parties.

# Electoral System

Malaysia uses a first-past-the-post electoral system, in which the candidate with the most votes in a constituency wins the seat. The country is divided into 222 parliamentary constituencies, each of which elects one MP to the Dewan Rakyat. The state legislatures are also elected using the same system.

# Timeline

## Dissolution of Parliament

The 14th Malaysian Parliament was dissolved on 10 October 2022, following which the Election Commission of Malaysia (EC) announced the dates for the general election.

## Dissolution of State Legislatures

Several state legislatures were also dissolved in the lead-up to the general election. The states of Sabah and Sarawak held their state elections in 2020 and 2021, respectively, and were not required to hold fresh elections.

## Pre-Nomination Events

Several pre-nomination events took place in the lead-up to the general election. The EC announced the dates for the nomination of candidates, which took place on 5 November 2022.

## Timetable

The EC announced the following timetable for the general election:

* 10 October 2022: Dissolution of Parliament
* 20 October 2022: Issue of writ of election
* 5 November 2022: Nomination of candidates
* 15 November 2022: Early voting
* 19 November 2022: Polling day
* 20 November 2022: Counting of votes

# Last Election Pendulum

The following is a list of marginal seats won by the various parties in the 2018 general election:

* Pakatan Harapan: 113 seats
	+ 30 seats with a majority of less than 1,000 votes
	+ 20 seats with a majority of between 1,000 and 5,000 votes
* Barisan Nasional: 79 seats
	+ 15 seats with a majority of less than 1,000 votes
	+ 10 seats with a majority of between 1,000 and 5,000 votes

# Political Parties and Candidates

## Parties Represented in Current Legislatures

The following parties were represented in the 14th Malaysian Parliament:

* Pakatan Harapan (PH)
* Barisan Nasional (BN)
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia (PAS)
* Parti Warisan Sabah (WARISAN)
* Parti Bersatu Sabah (PBS)
* Parti Bersatu Rakyat Sabah (PBRS)

## Extra-Parliamentary Parties

The following parties were not represented in the 14th Malaysian Parliament:

* Parti Keadilan Rakyat (PKR)
* Parti Amanah Negara (Amanah)
* Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (BERSATU)
* Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia (Gerakan)

## Nominated Candidates

A total of 945 candidates were nominated for the general election. The following is a breakdown of the number of candidates nominated by each party:

* Pakatan Harapan: 221 candidates
* Barisan Nasional: 178 candidates
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia: 74 candidates
* Parti Warisan Sabah: 52 candidates
* Parti Bersatu Sabah: 13 candidates
* Parti Bersatu Rakyat Sabah: 7 candidates

# Campaign

## Timing of Election

The general election was held on 19 November 2022, which was a Saturday. The EC announced that polling stations would be open from 8 am to 6 pm.

## Youth Vote

The general election saw a significant increase in the number of young voters. According to the EC, over 1.4 million new voters were registered for the general election, with the majority being between the ages of 18 and 21.

# Outgoing Members of Parliament

The following is a list of outgoing MPs who did not contest the general election:

* Mahathir Mohamad (Langkawi)
* Anwar Ibrahim (Port Dickson)
* Muhyiddin Yassin (P Pagoh)
* Ismail Sabri Yaakob (Bera)

# Opinion Polls

Several opinion polls were conducted in the lead-up to the general election. The following is a summary of the results:

* Pakatan Harapan: 40% - 50% of the vote
* Barisan Nasional: 30% - 40% of the vote
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia: 10% - 20% of the vote

# Results

## By Alliance

The following is a summary of the results by alliance:

* Pakatan Harapan: 82 seats
* Barisan Nasional: 30 seats
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia: 49 seats
* Parti Warisan Sabah: 3 seats
* Parti Bersatu Sabah: 1 seat
* Parti Bersatu Rakyat Sabah: 1 seat
* Independent: 2 seats

## By Parliamentary Seats

The following is a list of the winning candidates by parliamentary seat:

* Pakatan Harapan: 82 seats
	+ 40 seats in Selangor
	+ 20 seats in Penang
	+ 15 seats in Kuala Lumpur
	+ 7 seats in Johor
* Barisan Nasional: 30 seats
	+ 10 seats in Johor
	+ 7 seats in Sabah
	+ 5 seats in Sarawak
	+ 8 seats in Perak
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia: 49 seats
	+ 15 seats in Kelantan
	+ 10 seats in Terengganu
	+ 8 seats in Kedah
	+ 16 seats in Pahang

## State Assemblies

The following is a summary of the results by state assembly:

* Pakatan Harapan: 262 seats
	+ 102 seats in Selangor
	+ 60 seats in Penang
	+ 56 seats in Kuala Lumpur
	+ 44 seats in Johor
* Barisan Nasional: 134 seats
	+ 40 seats in Johor
	+ 29 seats in Sabah
	+ 25 seats in Sarawak
	+ 40 seats in Perak
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia: 122 seats
	+ 37 seats in Kelantan
	+ 25 seats in Terengganu
	+ 20 seats in Kedah
	+ 40 seats in Pahang

## Seats That Changed Allegiance

The following is a list of seats that changed allegiance:

* Pakatan Harapan: 20 seats
	+ 10 seats in Selangor
	+ 5 seats in Penang
	+ 3 seats in Kuala Lumpur
	+ 2 seats in Johor
* Barisan Nasional: 15 seats
	+ 5 seats in Johor
	+ 4 seats in Sabah
	+ 3 seats in Sarawak
	+ 3 seats in Perak
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia: 15 seats
	+ 5 seats in Kelantan
	+ 4 seats in Terengganu
	+ 3 seats in Kedah
	+ 3 seats in Pahang

# Aftermath

## Formation of Federal Government

The Pakatan Harapan coalition, led by Anwar Ibrahim, formed a federal government with the support of the Barisan Nasional coalition and several other parties.

## International Reactions

The international community congratulated Malaysia on a peaceful and successful general election. The United States, China, and Singapore were among the countries that issued statements congratulating the new government.

# See Also

* 2018 Malaysian general election
* 2020 Malaysian political crisis
* 2021 Malaysian state of emergency

# Notes

This article is based on information available up to 20 November 2022.

# References

None

# External Links

* Election Commission of Malaysia
* Malaysian Parliament
* Pakatan Harapan
* Barisan Nasional
* Parti Islam Se-Malaysia

article:
2023 FIFA Women's World Cup

The 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup is the ninth edition of the FIFA Women's World Cup, the quadrennial international women's football championship contested by national teams affiliated with FIFA. The tournament is scheduled to take place in Australia and New Zealand from July 20 to August 20, 2023.

# Overview

The 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup is the first edition of the tournament to be hosted by two countries, Australia and New Zealand. The tournament features 32 national teams, an increase from the 24 teams that participated in the 2019 edition. The tournament is expected to be one of the largest and most competitive women's sporting events in the world.

## Schedule

The tournament is scheduled to take place from July 20 to August 20, 2023. The group stage will feature 64 matches, with each team playing three matches. article:
2022 Nepalese local elections

The 2022 Nepalese local elections were held on May 13, 2022, to elect representatives to all 753 local governments in Nepal, including six metropolitan cities, 11 sub-metropolitan cities, 276 municipalities, and 460 village councils. The elections were originally scheduled for 2021 but were postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Electoral system

The 2022 Nepalese local elections used a mixed electoral system, combining elements of first-past-the-post (FPTP) and proportional representation (PR) systems.

## Qualification for candidates

To qualify as a candidate for the local elections, individuals had to meet certain eligibility criteria, including being a citizen of Nepal, being at least 25 years old (for mayoral and chairperson positions) or 20 years old (for other positions), and not having been convicted of a crime.

## Exit poll

Exit polls were conducted by several organizations, including the Nepal Election Observers' Group and the Centre for Investigative Journalism, to gauge voter sentiment and predict the outcome of the elections.

### Mayor/Chairperson post

The exit polls showed that the Nepali Congress (NC) was likely to win the majority of mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist-Leninist) (CPN-UML) and the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre) (CPN-MC).

Results

The results of the 2022 Nepalese local elections were declared on May 16, 2022, by the Election Commission of Nepal.

## Overall Results

The overall results showed that the Nepali Congress (NC) emerged as the largest party, winning 305 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 184 wins, the CPN-MC with 144 wins, and the Janata Samajbadi Party (JSP) with 26 wins.

## By province

### Province 1

In Province 1, the NC won 34 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 23 wins, and the CPN-MC with 15 wins.

### Madhesh Province

In Madhesh Province, the JSP won 14 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the NC with 10 wins, and the CPN-UML with 6 wins.

### Bagmati Province

In Bagmati Province, the NC won 25 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 18 wins, and the CPN-MC with 12 wins.

### Gandaki Province

In Gandaki Province, the NC won 19 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 12 wins, and the CPN-MC with 8 wins.

### Lumbini Province

In Lumbini Province, the NC won 22 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 15 wins, and the CPN-MC with 10 wins.

### Karnali Province

In Karnali Province, the NC won 12 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 8 wins, and the CPN-MC with 5 wins.

### Sudurpaschim Province

In Sudurpaschim Province, the NC won 14 mayoral and chairperson positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 10 wins, and the CPN-MC with 7 wins.

## Major cities

### Metropolitan cities

In the six metropolitan cities, the NC won 4 mayoral positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 2 wins.

### Sub-metropolitan cities

In the 11 sub-metropolitan cities, the NC won 7 mayoral positions, followed by the CPN-UML with 3 wins, and the CPN-MC with 1 win.

Incidents

Several incidents were reported during the 2022 Nepalese local elections, including allegations of vote rigging, violence, and intimidation of voters and candidates.

================

Piri is a British singer, songwriter, and record producer. She initially gained recognition as one half of the duo Piri & Tommy, before pursuing a solo career. Known for her distinctive vocal style and introspective songwriting, Piri has established herself as a rising talent in the UK music scene.

Life and Career

### 1999–2020: Early Life

Piri was born in 1999 in the United Kingdom. Growing up, she developed a passion for music, drawing inspiration from a wide range of genres, including R&B, pop, and electronic music. She began writing her own songs at a young age, honing her craft and developing her unique voice.

article:
Chandramukhi 2

Chandramukhi 2 is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language comedy horror film written and directed by P. Vasu. The film is a sequel to the 2005 film Chandramukhi, which was also directed by Vasu. The film stars Kangana Ranaut, Raghava Lawrence, and Vadivelu in lead roles.

# Plot

The film takes place several years after the events of the first film. Raghava Lawrence reprises his role as Saravanan, who is now married to Priya (played by a new actress) and has a daughter. However, their happiness is short-lived as a new evil spirit, Chandramukhi (played by Kangana Ranaut), begins to haunt them.

As the family tries to get rid of the ghost, they uncover the dark past of Chandramukhi, who was a princess in a royal family. The spirit is on a mission to avenge her own death and the death of her lover, which was caused by the royal family's greed and betrayal.

The film follows Saravanan's efforts to help Chandramukhi find peace and move on, while also dealing with the comedic misadventures of his family and friends. Along the way, the film features a range of humor, horror, and drama, making it a unique blend of genres.

# Cast

* Kangana Ranaut as Chandramukhi
* Raghava Lawrence as Saravanan
* Vadivelu as Murugesan
* Lakshmi Menon as Priya
* Senthil as Ganesan
* Kovai Sarala as Kasthuri
* Devadarshini as Surya

# Production

## Development

The idea for a sequel to Chandramukhi was first discussed in 2010, but it took several years to develop the script and secure funding. P. Vasu, who directed the original film, was brought on board to write and direct the sequel. The film was produced by Sun Pictures, which also produced the original film.

## Casting

Kangana Ranaut was cast as Chandramukhi, marking her debut in Tamil cinema. Raghava Lawrence, who played the lead role in the original film, was also cast in the sequel. Vadivelu, who played a supporting role in the original film, was also brought back for the sequel.

Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament

The Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament refers to a major corruption scandal that came to light in December 2022, involving allegations of bribery and corruption by officials of the European Parliament. The scandal centers around allegations that Qatar and other countries used bribery and other forms of corruption to influence the decisions of members of the European Parliament.

#Allegations and events leading up to the arrests

The allegations of corruption and bribery against Qatar and other countries first surfaced in the summer of 2022. It was reported that the Belgian Federal Police had launched an investigation into allegations of corruption and bribery by officials of the European Parliament. The investigation was reportedly sparked by a tip-off from a whistleblower, who claimed that several members of the European Parliament had received large sums of money and other gifts from Qatar and other countries in exchange for favorable treatment.

In the months leading up to the arrests, several members of the European Parliament were reportedly questioned by police and other investigators. The investigation focused on allegations of corruption and bribery related to Qatar's efforts to influence the decisions of the European Parliament on issues related to human rights, migration, and other topics.

#Investigation, raids and arrests

article:
Bigg Boss (Telugu TV series) season 7

Bigg Boss Telugu season 7, also known as Bigg Boss Telugu 7, is the seventh season of the Telugu version of the Indian reality television series Bigg Boss, which is based on the Dutch series Big Brother. The season premiered on 3 September 2023 and is being broadcast on Star Maa and streamed on Disney+ Hotstar. The show is hosted by Akkineni Nagarjuna.

# Production

## Eye Logo

The eye logo of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 was unveiled on 24 August 2023. The logo features a stylized eye with a hint of a smile, surrounded by a circle with a Telugu inscription that translates to "The Ultimate War".

## Teasers

The first teaser of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 was released on 24 August 2023, featuring the show's host, Akkineni Nagarjuna. The teaser hinted at the theme of the season, which is "The Ultimate War".

## Concept

The concept of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 is centered around the theme of "The Ultimate War", which is a metaphor for the conflicts and challenges that the housemates will face during their stay in the Bigg Boss house. The show's producers have promised that this season will be more intense and competitive than previous seasons.

## 24x7 streaming

Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 is being streamed 24x7 on Disney+ Hotstar, allowing viewers to watch the show at any time and from any location.

## Voting process

The voting process for Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 is similar to previous seasons. Viewers can vote for their favorite housemates through the Disney+ Hotstar app or by sending an SMS to the designated number. The housemate with the fewest votes will be eliminated from the show each week.

# Housemates status

The housemates of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 are competing against each other to win the title of Bigg Boss Telugu 7 and a cash prize of ₹50 lakh.

# Housemates

## Original entrants

The original entrants of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 are:

1. Aishwarya
2. Avinash
3. Bala Aditya
4. Bindu Madhavi
5. Deepthi Sunaina
6. Hamida
7. Kajal
8. Kalyan

The wild card entrants of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7, who entered the show during the 2.0 launch, are:

1. Kumar Sai
2. Mitraaw Sharma
3. Varun Sandesh

# Twists

## Money offer

In a surprising twist, Bigg Boss offered the housemates a chance to win ₹1 lakh each if they could complete a task within a certain time limit. The task involved the housemates working together to fill a tank with water using only a small cup.

## Power astra

The Power astra is a new twist introduced in Bigg Boss Telugu season 7. The Power astra is a special power that allows the holder to save one housemate from nomination or eviction.

## Bedroom allotment

In a surprise twist, Bigg Boss announced that the housemates would be allotted bedrooms based on their performance in a task. The task involved the housemates competing against each other to win the right to sleep in the most comfortable bedroom.

## Bigg Boss 2.0 launch

The Bigg Boss 2.0 launch was a special episode that marked the halfway point of the season. During the episode, the housemates were given a chance to reflect on their journey so far and the wild card entrants were introduced.

## Special powers HOL, HOB and HOK

The special powers HOL, HOB and HOK were introduced in Bigg Boss Telugu season 7. Naagin (2015 TV series)

Naagin is a popular Indian supernatural drama television series that premiered on November 1, 2015, on Colors TV. Produced by Balaji Telefilms, the show has become a massive hit among audiences and has been one of the highest-rated Indian television shows. The series revolves around the life of a shape-shifting snake woman, also known as an ichchhadhaari naagin, and her quest for revenge and love.

# Series overview

Naagin is a fantasy drama that explores the concept of shape-shifting snakes and their lives in human form. The show's narrative is full of twists and turns, with each season featuring a new story, new characters, and new locations. The series has been praised for its captivating storyline, impressive visual effects, and strong female leads.

# Plot

## Season 1

The first season of Naagin premiered on November 1, 2015, and starred Mouni Roy as Shivanya, a shape-shifting snake woman, and Arjun Bijlani as Ritik Singh, a wealthy businessman. The story revolves around Shivanya's quest for revenge against the people who killed her parents. She marries Ritik and enters his family, but things get complicated when Ritik's family is revealed to be involved in her parents' murder. The season ends with Shivanya's death, but her spirit lives on to take revenge in the next season.

## Season 2

The second season of Naagin premiered on October 8, 2016, and introduced a new lead character, Shivangi (played by Mouni Roy), Shivanya's daughter. The story takes a leap of 25 years and follows Shivangi's journey as she seeks revenge against her parents' killers. The season also introduces a new antagonist, Rocky (played by Karishma Tanna), a shape-shifting snake woman who becomes Shivangi's rival. The season ends with Shivangi's death, but her spirit lives on to take revenge in the next season.

## Season 3

The third season of Naagin premiered on June 2, 2018, and introduced a new lead character, Bela (played by Surbhi Jyoti), a shape-shifting snake woman. The story revolves around Bela's quest for revenge against the people who killed her parents. She marries Mahir (played by Pearl V Puri), a wealthy businessman, and enters his family, but things get complicated when Mahir's family is revealed to be involved in her parents' murder. The season ends with Bela's transformation into a powerful shape-shifting snake woman.

## Season 4

The fourth season of Naagin premiered on December 14, 2019, and introduced a new lead character, Brinda (played by Nia Sharma), a shape-shifting snake woman. The story revolves around Brinda's quest for revenge against the people who killed her husband. She marries Dev (played by Vijayendra Kumeria), a wealthy businessman, and enters his family, but things get complicated when Dev's family is revealed to be involved in her husband's murder. The season ends with Brinda's transformation into a powerful shape-shifting snake woman.

## Season 5

The fifth season of Naagin premiered on August 9, 2020, and introduced a new lead character, Bani (played by Surbhi Chandna), a shape-shifting snake woman. The story revolves around Bani's quest for revenge against the people who killed her husband. She marries Veer (played by Sharad Malhotra), a wealthy businessman, and enters his family, but things get complicated when Veer's family is revealed to be involved in her husband's murder. The season ends with Bani's transformation into a powerful shape-shifting snake woman.

## Basant Panchami Special

A special episode of Naagin aired on January 26, 2021, to celebrate the festival of Basant Panchami. The episode featured a special storyline where Bani and her friends celebrated the festival and fought against evil forces.

## Season 6

The sixth season of Naagin premiered on February 12, 2022, and introduced a new lead character, Pratha (played by Tejasswi Prakash), a shape-shifting snake woman. The story revolves around Pratha's quest for revenge against the people who killed her husband. She marries Rishabh (played by Simba Nagpal), a wealthy businessman, and enters his family, but things get complicated when Rishabh's family is revealed to be involved in her husband's murder.

article:
Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2
================

Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 is a 2022 Indian Hindi-language comedy horror film directed by Anees Bazmee and produced by Bhushan Kumar and Krishan Kumar under the banner of T-Series. The film is a standalone sequel to the 2007 film Bhool Bhulaiyaa, and stars Kartik Aaryan, Kiara Advani, and Tabu in the lead roles.

Plot
-----

The film follows the story of Ruhan Randhawa (Kartik Aaryan), a charming and carefree young man who falls in love with Reet Thakur (Kiara Advani), a level-headed and ambitious woman. The two get married and move to a new city, where they shift into a sprawling mansion that has been locked up for years. Unbeknownst to them, the mansion has a dark history, and they soon discover that it is haunted by the ghost of a former occupant, Manjulika (Tabu).

As Ruhan and Reet try to navigate their new life together, they begin to experience strange and terrifying occurrences in the mansion. They soon discover that Manjulika's spirit is still trapped within the mansion, and that she is seeking revenge on the living. Ruhan, who is initially skeptical of the paranormal activity, soon finds himself face-to-face with the vengeful spirit.

Cast
-----

* Kartik Aaryan as Ruhan Randhawa
* Kiara Advani as Reet Thakur
* Tabu as Manjulika
* Rajpal Yadav as Chhote Pandit
* Sanjay Mishra as Bade Pandit
* Kriti Sanon as special appearance in the song "Ami Je Tomar"

Production
-----------

### Development

The film was first announced in 2019, with Kartik Aaryan and Kiara Advani attached to star. Anees Bazmee was brought on board to direct the film, and the script was written by Farhad Samji and Aakash Kaushik. The film is a standalone sequel to the 2007 film Bhool Bhulaiyaa, which was directed by Priyadarshan and starred Akshay Kumar, Vidya Balan, and Shiney Ahuja.

### Filming

Principal photography for the film began in October 2019, and wrapped up in February 2020. The film was shot on location in Jaipur, Rajasthan, and in studios in Mumbai. The film's production was halted temporarily in March 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but resumed in September 2020.

Release
-------

### Theatrical

Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 was initially set to release on July 31, 2020, but was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The film was later rescheduled to release on March 19, 2021, but was again postponed due to the second wave of the pandemic. The film finally released on May 20, 2022, in theaters across India.

### Home media

The film was released on the streaming platform Netflix on June 19, 2022, and on the satellite channel Sony Max on July 17, 2022.

Soundtrack
----------

The film's soundtrack was composed by Pritam, and the lyrics were written by Sameer, Amitabh Bhattacharya, and Shabbir Ahmed. The soundtrack features six tracks, including the popular songs "Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 (Title Track)", "Hum Nashe Mein Toh Nahin", and "Ami Je Tomar". The soundtrack was released on May 16, 2022, on the music streaming platform JioSaavn.

Reception
----------

### Critical response

Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 received mixed reviews from critics, who praised the film's performances, music, and production values, but criticized its predictable plot and lack of originality. Kartik Aaryan and Kiara Advani's performances were widely praised, with many critics noting that they had great chemistry on screen. Tabu's performance as the vengeful spirit Manjulika was also widely praised, with many critics noting that she stole the show.

### Box office

Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 was a commercial success at the box office, grossing over ₹ 250 crore worldwide. The film opened to a strong start at the box office, collecting over ₹ 14 crore on its opening day. The film's collections slowed down in the following weeks, but it still managed to gross over ₹ 100 crore in its first week. The film's success was seen as a major boost to the Indian film industry, which had been struggling to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Sequel
------

In June 2022, it was announced that a sequel to Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 was in the works, with Kartik Aaryan and Kiara Advani set to reprise their roles. The sequel is expected to be directed by Anees Bazmee, and the script is being written by Farhad Samji and Aakash Kaushik.

article:
2023 FIVB Volleyball Women's Olympic Qualification Tournaments

The 2023 FIVB Volleyball Women's Olympic Qualification Tournaments were a series of volleyball tournaments held from September 16 to October 15, 2023, to determine the participating teams for the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, France. A total of 24 teams competed in the qualification process, with the top teams earning a spot in the Olympic tournament.

# Hosts selection

The FIVB announced the hosts for the Olympic qualification tournaments on March 10, 2023. The three host cities were Ningbo, China; Tokyo, Japan; and Łódź, Poland. The selection of hosts was based on a bidding process, with the FIVB considering factors such as the quality of the venues, the experience of the organizing committee, and the overall volleyball tradition in the country.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2024 Summer Olympics involved a combination of direct qualification and Olympic qualification tournaments. The top three teams from the 2022 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, as well as the top two teams from each of the five continental championships, earned direct qualification to the Olympic tournament. The remaining teams competed in the Olympic qualification tournaments to determine the final spots.

# Pools composition

The 24 teams competing in the Olympic qualification tournaments were divided into three pools of eight teams each. The pools were composed based on the FIVB World Rankings, with the top-ranked teams placed in Pool A, the next top-ranked teams in Pool B, and the remaining teams in Pool C. The teams were then drawn into their respective pools in a random manner.

# Venues

The Olympic qualification tournaments were held in three different venues:

* Ningbo, China: Ningbo Sports Center Gymnasium (capacity: 5,000)
* Tokyo, Japan: Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium (capacity: 10,000)
* Łódź, Poland: Atlas Arena (capacity: 13,000)

# Pool standing procedure

The teams in each pool competed in a round-robin format, with each team playing every other team in their pool once. The teams were ranked based on their win-loss record, with the top teams earning the most points. In the event of a tie, the teams were ranked based on their set ratio, and then their point ratio.

# Squads

Each team was allowed to register a maximum of 14 players for the Olympic qualification tournaments. The teams were required to submit their squads to the FIVB at least 10 days prior to the start of the tournament.

# Result

## Pool A (Ningbo, China)

The 2022 North Indian Ocean cyclone season was the annual cycle of tropical cyclone formation and activity in the North Indian Ocean, which includes the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea. The season officially began on April 1, 2022, and ended on December 31, 2022.

# Season summary

The 2022 North Indian Ocean cyclone season was a moderately active season, with a total of 14 depressions, 7 deep depressions, 4 cyclonic storms, and 2 severe cyclonic storms. 2022 Winter Olympics

The 2022 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXIV Olympic Winter Games, took place in Beijing, China, from February 4 to February 20, 2022. Beijing became the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympics, having previously hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics. The 2022 Winter Olympics featured a total of 2,871 athletes from 91 National Olympic Committees (NOCs) competing in 109 events across 15 sports.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the 2022 Winter Olympics began in 2013, with six cities initially expressing interest in hosting the Games. However, by the time the bidding process concluded in 2015, only two cities remained: Beijing, China, and Almaty, Kazakhstan. Beijing won the bid on July 31, 2015, with 44 votes to Almaty's 40.

# Development and preparations

## Venues

The 2022 Winter Olympics featured a total of 13 venues, with 11 in Beijing and 2 in Zhangjiakou. The venues were divided into three clusters: Beijing, Yanqing, and Zhangjiakou.

### Beijing Zone

The Beijing Zone featured six venues: the Beijing National Stadium (Bird's Nest), the Beijing National Aquatics Center (Water Cube), the Beijing National Indoor Stadium, the Capital Gymnasium, the Wukesong Sports Center, and the Big Air Shougang.

### Zhangjiakou Zone

The Zhangjiakou Zone featured two venues: the National Ski Jumping Center and the National Cross-Country Skiing Center.

## Medals

The medals for the 2022 Winter Olympics were designed by Hang Hai, a Chinese artist. The medals featured a traditional Chinese design, with a circular shape and a diameter of 85.7 mm. The medals were made of 24-karat gold, silver, and copper.

## Torch relay

The torch relay for the 2022 Winter Olympics began on October 18, 2021, in Olympia, Greece. The relay covered a distance of over 7,500 km, passing through 19 provinces and municipalities in China.

## Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the 2022 Winter Olympics. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) implemented a series of measures to mitigate the risk of transmission, including a "closed-loop" system that separated athletes, officials, and spectators from the general public. Spectators were also limited to a maximum of 30% of the venue capacity.

## Transportation

The 2022 Winter Olympics featured a comprehensive transportation system, including high-speed trains, buses, and taxis. The Beijing-Zhangjiakou high-speed railway, which was completed in 2019, connected the two cities and reduced travel time to just 50 minutes.

## Budget

The budget for the 2022 Winter Olympics was estimated to be around $3.9 billion, making it one of the most expensive Winter Olympics in history.

The opening ceremony of the 2022 Winter Olympics took place on February 4, 2022, at the Beijing National Stadium. ## Closing ceremony

# Irene Mawer

Irene Mawer (1900-1962) was a British artist and illustrator, best known for her work on the iconic Ladybird Books series. Her distinctive style and attention to detail have made her one of the most beloved and recognizable illustrators of her generation. Through her contributions to children's literature, Mawer played a significant role in shaping the visual aesthetic of mid-20th-century British culture.

# Early life and education

Irene Mawer was born in 1900 in London, England. Her early life and education are not well-documented, but it is known that she developed a passion for art at a young age. Mawer went on to study at the Royal College of Art, where she honed her skills as an illustrator and fine artist.

## Artistic training and influences

During her time at the Royal College of Art, Mawer was exposed to a wide range of artistic styles and influences. She was particularly drawn to the work of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, whose emphasis on detail and realism resonated with her own artistic vision. Mawer's early work also shows a strong debt to the Arts and Crafts movement, with its emphasis on handcraftsmanship and attention to detail.

# Career

Irene Mawer's career as an illustrator began in the 1920s, when she started working on a range of projects, including book covers, advertisements, and editorial illustrations. Her big break came in the 1940s, when she was approached by Henry Wills & Co., the publishers of Ladybird Books, to work on a series of titles.

## Ladybird Books

Mawer's work on Ladybird Books is arguably her most enduring legacy. Her illustrations, which appeared in over 100 titles, are characterized by their attention to detail, warmth, and sense of nostalgia. Mawer's distinctive style, which blended traditional and modern elements, helped to establish Ladybird Books as a beloved and iconic brand.

## Other projects and collaborations

In addition to her work on Ladybird Books, Mawer collaborated with other authors and publishers on a range of projects. She worked with the renowned children's author, Enid Blyton, on several titles, and also contributed to a number of educational textbooks and magazines.

# Influence and legacy

article:
2023 Karnataka Legislative Assembly election

The 2023 Karnataka Legislative Assembly election was a state assembly election scheduled to be held in Karnataka, India, to elect the 224 members of the Karnataka Legislative Assembly. The election was held in a single phase on May 10, 2023. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), Indian National Congress (INC), and Janata Dal (Secular) (JD(S)) were the main parties contesting the election. The election was significant as it was the first major state election in India after the 2022 national budget and had implications for the 2024 Indian general election.

Background

The 2023 Karnataka Legislative Assembly election was the 16th election to be held in the state since the formation of the Karnataka Legislative Assembly in 1956. The state was under the President's rule from May 19, 2018, to July 26, 2019, after the fall of the JD(S)-INC coalition government. The BJP formed the government in July 2019, with B. S. Yediyurappa as the Chief Minister.

Political developments

Defections before polls

In the run-up to the election, several MLAs from the INC and JD(S) defected to the BJP. The MLAs who defected included some prominent leaders, such as R. Shankar and R. Shankar. The defections were seen as a major blow to the INC and JD(S) and were expected to impact their chances in the election.

Schedule

The Election Commission of India announced the schedule for the election on March 29, 2023. The election was held in a single phase on May 10, 2023. The counting of votes was held on May 13, 2023.

Election statistics

Electorate

The total electorate in Karnataka for the 2023 election was 5,23,46,745, including 2,61,49,813 male and 2,61,96,932 female voters.

Polling stations

There were 58,545 polling stations set up across the state for the election.

Parties contesting

Bharatiya Janata Party

The BJP was the main opposition party in the state and was contesting the election with the aim of coming to power. The party had a strong organizational structure in the state and was expected to perform well.

Indian National Congress

The INC was the main ruling party in the state and was contesting the election with the aim of retaining power. The party had faced several challenges in the run-up to the election, including defections and internal conflicts.

Janata Dal (Secular)

The JD(S) was a regional party that had a significant presence in the state. The party was contesting the election with the aim of increasing its tally.

Others

Other parties contesting the election included the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP), and the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPI(M)).

Candidates

The BJP fielded candidates in all 224 constituencies, while the INC and JD(S) fielded candidates in 223 and 213 constituencies, respectively.

Issues

Belagavi border dispute

The Belagavi border dispute was a major issue in the election. The dispute was between Karnataka and Maharashtra over the status of the Belagavi district, which was claimed by both states.

Corruption

Corruption was a major issue in the election, with several parties promising to tackle the issue if they came to power.

Communal polarization

Communal polarization was a major issue in the election, with several parties accused of indulging in communal politics.

Reservation controversy

The reservation controversy was a major issue in the election, with several parties promising to increase the reservation quota for certain communities.

Farm laws

The farm laws were a major issue in the election, with several parties promising to repeal the laws if they came to power.

Nandini vs Amul

The Nandini vs Amul controversy was a major issue in the election, with several parties promising to promote the local dairy cooperative, Nandini.

Controversies

Remarks on 'Love jihad'

The BJP was accused of using the 'Love jihad' controversy to polarize voters. The party's leaders made several remarks on the issue, which were seen as inflammatory.

Provocative statements by Amit Shah

Amit Shah, the Home Minister of India and the BJP's national president, made several provocative statements during the election campaign. His statements were seen as an attempt to polarize voters.

Supreme Court remarks on his speeches

The Supreme Court made several remarks on Amit Shah's speeches, saying that they were inflammatory and had the potential to polarize voters.

Collection and sale of voter data

There were allegations of the collection and sale of voter data during the election. The allegations were made by several parties, including the INC and JD(S).

Kharge remark on PM Modi

M. Mallikarjun Kharge, the INC's national president, made a remark on Prime Minister Narendra Modi, which was seen as inflammatory.

Congress manifesto promise to ban Bajrang Dal

The INC's manifesto promised to ban the Bajrang Dal, a right-wing organization. The promise was seen as an attempt to polarize voters.

Conspiracy to assassinate Kharge

There were allegations of a conspiracy to assassinate M. Mallikarjun Kharge during the election campaign.

Questions on fairness of Election Commission

There were questions on the fairness of the Election Commission during the election. The commission was accused of being biased towards the BJP.

Sonia Gandhi speech

Sonia Gandhi, the INC's national president, made a speech during the election campaign, which was seen as an attempt to polarize voters.

Campaigns

Bharatiya Janata Party

Manifesto

The BJP's manifesto promised several things, including the promotion of local industries and the creation of jobs.

Indian National Congress

Manifesto

The INC's manifesto promised several things, including the promotion of local industries and the creation of jobs.

Janata Dal (Secular)

Manifesto

The JD(S)'s manifesto promised several things, including the promotion of local industries and the creation of jobs.

Surveys

Opinion polls

Several opinion polls were conducted during the election campaign, which showed that the BJP was ahead of the INC and JD(S).

Exit polls

Several exit polls were conducted after the election, which showed that the BJP was ahead of the INC and JD(S).

Results

Vote share

The BJP got 35.6% of the total vote share, while the INC got 31.4% and the JD(S) got 19.3%.

Seat share

The BJP won 120 seats, while the INC won 87 seats and the JD(S) won 19 seats.

article:
The Last of Us (TV series)

The Last of Us is a post-apocalyptic drama television series based on the 2013 video game of the same name developed by Naughty Dog. The series premiered in 2023 and has received widespread critical acclaim for its storytelling, characters, and faithfulness to the original game.

# Cast and characters

## Main

The series features a talented ensemble cast, including Pedro Pascal as Joel, a hardened survivor tasked with escorting a young girl named Ellie (played by Bella Ramsey) across a post-apocalyptic United States. Other main cast members include Gabriel Luna as Tommy, Joel's brother, and Merle Dandridge as Marlene, the leader of the resistance group known as the Fireflies.

## Guest

Several notable actors appear in guest roles throughout the series, including Nico Parker as Sarah, Joel's daughter, and Murray Bartlett as Frank, a survivor who becomes embroiled in Joel and Ellie's journey. Other guest stars include Nick Offerman as Bill, a paranoid survivalist, and Anna Torv as Tess, a member of the Fireflies.

## Season 2

The second season of The Last of Us is currently in production, with several new cast members joining the show. This includes Storm Reid as Riley Abel, a character from the video game's prequel, The Last of Us: Left Behind. Other new cast members include Lamar Johnson as Henry, a young man who becomes a key ally to Joel and Ellie, and Graham Greene as Marlon, a leader of a group of survivors.

# Episodes

## Season 1 (2023)

The first season of The Last of Us consists of nine episodes, each approximately 45 minutes long. The season follows Joel and Ellie's journey across the United States, as they navigate the dangers of the post-apocalyptic world and confront their own personal demons. The episodes are:

1. "When You're Lost in the Darkness"
2. "Infected"
3. "Long, Long Time"
4. "Please Hold My Hand"
5. "Endure and Survive"
6. "Kin"
7. "Left Behind"
8. "When We Are in Need"
9. "Look for the Light"

## Season 2

The second season of The Last of Us is expected to consist of at least eight episodes, although an official episode count has not been confirmed. The season is expected to continue the story of Joel and Ellie, as they face new challenges and enemies in the post-apocalyptic world.

# Production

## Development

The development of The Last of Us television series began in 2014, when Naughty Dog announced that a TV adaptation of the game was in the works. The project was initially set up at Sony Pictures Television, with Craig Mazin (Chernobyl) attached as writer and executive producer. In 2020, HBO acquired the rights to the series, with Mazin and Neil Druckmann (the creator of the video game) serving as co-creators and executive producers.

## Casting

The casting process for The Last of Us began in 2020, with Pedro Pascal and Bella Ramsey announced as Joel and Ellie, respectively. The cast was rounded out over the next year, with Gabriel Luna, Merle Dandridge, and Nico Parker joining the show.

## Writing

The writing team for The Last of Us includes Craig Mazin and Neil Druckmann, as well as several other writers who worked on the video game and other TV shows. The writers' room for the show is known for its collaborative approach, with input from the cast, crew, and game developers.

## Filming

Principal photography for The Last of Us began in July 2021, in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. The show was filmed on location in several different locations, including Alberta, Utah, and New Mexico. The production team used a combination of practical and visual effects to bring the post-apocalyptic world to life.

## Music

The music for The Last of Us was composed by Gustavo Santaolalla and Mac Quayle. The score features a combination of orchestral and acoustic elements, and has been praised for its emotional depth and complexity.

## Design and post-production

The design and post-production team for The Last of Us includes several notable artists and technicians, including production designer John Paino and visual effects supervisor Alex Wang. The show's visual effects were created by a team of artists and technicians at several different companies, including Weta Digital and Pixomondo.

# Release

## Broadcast and home media

The Last of Us premiered on HBO in January 2023, and is available to stream on HBO Max. The show has also been released on DVD and Blu-ray, and is available to purchase or rent on several different digital platforms.

## Promotion

The promotion for The Last of Us began several months before the show's premiere, with a series of trailers and teasers released on social media and online. The show's cast and crew also participated in several promotional events, including a panel at Comic-Con and a premiere screening in Los Angeles.

# Reception

## Critical response

The Last of Us has received widespread critical acclaim, with praise for its storytelling, characters, and faithfulness to the original game. The show has a 96% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising its emotional depth and complexity.

## Ratings

The Last of Us has been a ratings success for HBO, with several episodes drawing large audiences and high ratings. The show's premiere episode drew over 4 million viewers, making it one of the network's most-watched debuts in recent years.

## Awards and nominations

The Last of Us has been nominated for several awards, including several Primetime Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe Award. The show has also won several awards, including a Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Drama Series.

# Notes

The Last of Us is the first television series to be based on a video game, and has been widely praised for its faithfulness to the original game. The show's success has also led to the development of several other TV adaptations of video games, including a series based on the game "Halo".

2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup

The 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup was the 16th staging of the Rugby League World Cup, a quadrennial international rugby league tournament contested by the top national teams. The tournament was held in England from October 15 to November 19, 2021.

# Teams

## Qualification

The qualification process for the 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup began in 2018 and concluded in 2021. A total of 16 teams qualified for the tournament, with England receiving automatic qualification as the host nation. The remaining 15 teams were determined through a series of qualifying matches and competitions.

## Draw

The draw for the 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup took place on January 16, 2020, at Buckingham Palace in London. The 16 teams were divided into four groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

## Squads

Each team was allowed to name a squad of 24 players for the tournament. The squads were announced in the weeks leading up to the tournament, with several teams making changes to their squads due to injury or other reasons.

# Venues

## Stadium locations

The 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup was held at 21 stadiums across England. The stadiums were located in various cities and towns, including London, Manchester, Leeds, and Hull.

## Team base camp locations

Each team was allocated a base camp location for the duration of the tournament. The base camps were located in various cities and towns, including Leeds, Wigan, and St Helens.

# Officiating

## Match officials

A total of 24 match officials were appointed for the 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup. The match officials were from various countries, including Australia, England, and New Zealand.

## On-field rules and disciplinary measures

The 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup was played under the standard rules of rugby league, with several modifications to the rules and disciplinary measures in place to ensure player safety and fair play.

# Warm-up matches

Several warm-up matches were played in the weeks leading up to the tournament, with teams competing against each other in friendly matches to prepare for the tournament.

# Group stage

The group stage of the 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup took place from October 15 to October 31, 2021. The 16 teams were divided into four groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

## Group A

Group A consisted of England, Samoa, France, and Greece. England topped the group with three wins from three matches, while Samoa finished second with two wins from three matches.

## Group B

Group B consisted of Australia, Fiji, Scotland, and Italy. Australia topped the group with three wins from three matches, while Fiji finished second with two wins from three matches.

## Group C

Group C consisted of New Zealand, Lebanon, Jamaica, and Ireland. New Zealand topped the group with three wins from three matches, while Lebanon finished second with two wins from three matches.

## Group D

Group D consisted of Tonga, Papua New Guinea, Wales, and Cook Islands. Tonga topped the group with three wins from three matches, while Papua New Guinea finished second with two wins from three matches.

# Knockout stage

The knockout stage of the 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup took place from November 5 to November 19, 2021.

## Quarter-finals

The quarter-finals took place on November 5 and November 6, 2021. The matches were:

* England vs Papua New Guinea
* Australia vs Lebanon
* New Zealand vs Fiji
* Tonga vs Samoa

## Semi-finals

The semi-finals took place on November 12 and November 13, 2021. The matches were:

* England vs Samoa
* Australia vs Papua New Guinea

## Final

The final took place on November 19, 2021, at Old Trafford in Manchester. Australia defeated Samoa 30-10 in the final to win the 2021 Men's Rugby League World Cup.

article:
Penny Mordaunt

Penelope Mary Mordaunt is a British politician who has been the Member of Parliament (MP) for Portsmouth North since 2010. She has held various ministerial positions in the Conservative government, including Secretary of State for International Development, Minister for Women and Equalities, and Secretary of State for Defence.

#Early life and education

Mordaunt was born on March 4, 1973, in Torquay, Devon, England. She was raised in a naval family and spent part of her childhood in Singapore. She was educated at Oaklands Catholic School in Waterlooville, Hampshire, and later studied philosophy at the University of Reading. After graduating, she worked in the private sector, including a stint as a marketing manager for the company, Flying Colours.

#Early professional career

Before entering politics, Mordaunt worked in various roles, including as a director of the communications company, Haymarket Group, and as a consultant for the Conservative Party. She was also a member of the party's national policy committee and served as the chairman of the party's youth wing, Conservative Future.

#Entry into parliament

Mordaunt was first elected to parliament in the 2010 general election, representing the constituency of Portsmouth North. She won the seat with a majority of 7,289 votes, succeeding the incumbent Labour MP, Sarah McCarthy-Fry. In her maiden speech, Mordaunt highlighted the importance of supporting the armed forces and the need for economic growth in the region.

#Ministerial career

##Secretary of State for International Development: 2017–2019

Mordaunt was appointed Secretary of State for International Development in November 2017, following the resignation of Priti Patel. In this role, she was responsible for overseeing the UK's international aid budget and promoting economic development in developing countries. During her tenure, she launched several initiatives aimed at improving the lives of women and girls in developing countries, including a program to provide education and economic opportunities for girls in Africa.

##Minister for Women and Equalities: 2018–2019

In addition to her role as Secretary of State for International Development, Mordaunt was also appointed Minister for Women and Equalities in January 2018. In this role, she was responsible for promoting women's rights and equality in the UK. She launched several initiatives aimed at reducing the gender pay gap and improving the representation of women in business and politics.

##Secretary of State for Defence: 2019

Mordaunt was appointed Secretary of State for Defence in May 2019, following the resignation of Gavin Williamson. In this role, she was responsible for overseeing the UK's armed forces and defense policy. During her tenure, she launched several initiatives aimed at improving the welfare of military personnel and their families.

##Re-entry into Government

After losing her ministerial position in the 2019 reshuffle, Mordaunt returned to the backbenches. However, she was reappointed to the government in 2022, when she was appointed Leader of the House of Commons.

##Leader of the House of Commons: 2022–2024

As Leader of the House of Commons, Mordaunt was responsible for overseeing the legislative agenda and promoting the government's policies in parliament. She was also responsible for managing the parliamentary business of the government and ensuring the smooth operation of the House of Commons.

#Conservative leadership bids

##July–September 2022

Mordaunt stood as a candidate in the Conservative leadership election in July 2022, following the resignation of Boris Johnson. She was one of the initial frontrunners in the contest but was eliminated in the second round of voting.

##October 2022

Mordaunt again stood as a candidate in the Conservative leadership election in October 2022, following the resignation of Liz Truss. However, she withdrew from the contest before the first round of voting, citing a lack of support from fellow MPs.

#Military service

Mordaunt has a long-standing interest in the military and has served as a reservist in the Royal Navy. She was commissioned as a sub-lieutenant in 2010 and served for several years, including a stint as a lieutenant commander.

#Views and activities

##Splash! appearance

In 2014, Mordaunt appeared on the ITV reality TV show Splash!, where she competed against other celebrities in a diving competition. She was eliminated in the second round of the competition.

##Brexit

Mordaunt supported the Leave campaign in the 2016 EU referendum and has been a strong advocate for Brexit. She has argued that the UK's departure from the EU provides opportunities for the country to forge new trade relationships and promote economic growth.

##Northern Ireland

Mordaunt has been a strong supporter of the Union and has argued that the UK should take a tough stance on issues related to Northern Ireland. She has also advocated for the restoration of the Northern Ireland Assembly.

##Homeopathy

Mordaunt has been a vocal critic of homeopathy and has argued that it has no scientific basis. She has called for the NHS to stop funding homeopathic treatments.

##Muslim Council of Britain meeting

In 2018, Mordaunt was criticized for meeting with the Muslim Council of Britain, which has been accused of promoting extremist views. She defended the meeting, arguing that it was important to engage with all sections of the community.

##Royal yachts

Mordaunt has been a strong supporter of the proposal to build a new royal yacht, which would serve as a symbol of British industry and diplomacy. She has argued that the yacht would provide a valuable platform for promoting British trade and culture.

##Vandalism of war memorials

Mordaunt has been a strong critic of vandalism against war memorials and has argued that those responsible should face the full force of the law. She has also advocated for greater protection for war memorials and other historic sites.

#Personal life

Mordaunt is married to Paul Murray, a businessman. She is a Roman Catholic and has spoken about the importance of her faith in her life.

#Decorations

Mordaunt has been awarded several honors for her service, including the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in 2013.

#Publications

Mordaunt has written several articles and book chapters on topics related to politics and international development. She has also contributed to several newspapers and magazines, including The Times and The Spectator.

article:
Municipal History of Quebec

The municipal history of Quebec is a complex and multifaceted subject that spans over four centuries. From the early colonial era to the present day, the province of Quebec has undergone numerous transformations, shaped by its unique cultural, social, and economic context. This article provides an overview of the major developments in Quebec's municipal history, from the early 17th century to the present day.

# 1599 to 1793

## 1599
In 1599, the French Crown granted the Company of New France a monopoly on the fur trade in the region, marking the beginning of European settlement in what is now Quebec. The company established a series of trading posts and settlements, including the city of Quebec, which was founded in 1608.

## 1608
In 1608, Samuel de Champlain, a French explorer and administrator, founded the city of Quebec, which would become the capital of New France. The city was established as a fortified settlement, with a strategic location on the Saint Lawrence River.

## 1634
In 1634, the French Crown granted the city of Quebec a municipal charter, giving it the right to govern itself. The charter established a council of notables, made up of prominent citizens, to manage the city's affairs.

## 1642
In 1642, the French Crown granted the city of Montreal a municipal charter, making it the second city in New France to be granted self-government.

## 1793
In 1793, the British Crown, which had conquered New France in 1763, passed the Constitutional Act, which divided the province into two separate entities: Upper Canada (now Ontario) and Lower Canada (now Quebec). The act also established a system of municipal government, with elected councils and mayors.

# 19th century

## 1802
In 1802, the British government passed the Municipalities Act, which established a system of municipal government in Lower Canada. The act created a network of municipalities, each with its own elected council and mayor.

## 1832
In 1832, the British government passed the Reform Act, which expanded the right to vote in municipal elections. The act also established a system of elected mayors and councils in the larger cities.

## 1841
In 1841, the British government passed the Union Act, which united Upper and Lower Canada into a single entity, known as the Province of Canada.

## 1845
In 1845, the Province of Canada passed the Municipalities Act, which reformed the system of municipal government. The act established a system of elected councils and mayors, and gave municipalities greater autonomy.

## 1846
In 1846, the city of Montreal became the first city in Canada to adopt a charter of incorporation, giving it greater autonomy and powers of self-government.

## 1847
In 1847, the Province of Canada passed the Education Act, which established a system of public education. The act also gave municipalities the power to tax property owners to support education.

## 1848
In 1848, the Province of Canada passed the Municipalities Act, which reformed the system of municipal government. The act established a system of elected councils and mayors, and gave municipalities greater autonomy.

## 1849
In 1849, the city of Quebec became the capital of the Province of Canada, following the passage of the Act of Union.

## 1850
In 1850, the Province of Canada passed the Municipalities Act, which reformed the system of municipal government. The act established a system of elected councils and mayors, and gave municipalities greater autonomy.

## 1852
In 1852, the city of Montreal became the first city in Canada to establish a public transportation system, with the creation of the Montreal Street Railway Company.

## 1853

Kalki 2898 AD

Kalki 2898 AD is a forthcoming Indian science fiction film written and directed by Nag Ashwin, starring Prabhas, Deepika Padukone, and Amitabh Bachchan in lead roles. The film is set in a post-apocalyptic world and is expected to be released in 2023.

#Plot

The film is set in a dystopian future, specifically in the year 2898 AD. The story revolves around the protagonist, Kalki, played by Prabhas, who is a skilled warrior and a leader of a group of survivors. The world has been devastated by a catastrophic event, and the remaining humans are struggling to survive in a harsh environment.

As Kalki navigates through the treacherous landscape, he discovers a hidden city that holds the key to the survival of humanity. However, he soon realizes that he is not the only one searching for the city, and he must fight against various enemies to protect his people and uncover the secrets of the city.

Deepika Padukone plays the role of a scientist who helps Kalki on his mission, while Amitabh Bachchan appears as a wise and experienced mentor who guides Kalki through the challenges he faces.

#Cast

* Prabhas as Kalki
* Deepika Padukone as a scientist
* Amitabh Bachchan as a wise mentor
* Disha Patani as a skilled warrior
* Jackie Shroff as a villainous character

##Cameo appearances

* Kamal Haasan as a futuristic version of himself
* Rajinikanth as a holographic projection of a wise leader
* Aishwarya Rai Bachchan as a mysterious woman with a hidden agenda

#Production

##Development

The idea for Kalki 2898 AD was conceived by Nag Ashwin, who is known for his work on the film Mahanati. Ashwin was fascinated by the concept of a post-apocalyptic world and wanted to create a story that would explore the human condition in the face of catastrophic events.

The script was developed over a period of several months, with Ashwin working closely with his team of writers to create a compelling narrative.

##Pre-production

Pre-production work on the film began in 2020, with the team working on the visual effects, costumes, and production design.

The film's budget was estimated to be around ₹500 crore, making it one of the most expensive Indian films ever made.

##Casting

The casting process for the film was extensive, with the team searching for actors who could bring depth and nuance to their roles.

Prabhas was the first actor to be cast, followed by Deepika Padukone and Amitabh Bachchan.

##Filming

Principal photography for the film began in 2022 and took place in various locations across India and abroad.

The film's action sequences were choreographed by a team of international stunt coordinators, while the visual effects were handled by a team of experts from the United States and the United Kingdom.

##Post-production

Post-production work on the film began in 2022, with the team working on the editing, sound design, and visual effects.

The film's music was composed by a team of musicians, with the score being recorded in various locations across the world.

#Music

The film's music was composed by a team of musicians, including A. R. Rahman and Ilaiyaraaja.

The soundtrack features a mix of electronic and orchestral elements, with lyrics written by various poets and songwriters.

#Marketing

The marketing campaign for the film began in 2022, with the team releasing a series of teasers and trailers that showcased the film's action sequences and visual effects.

The film's poster was designed by a team of graphic designers, with the image featuring Prabhas in a futuristic costume.

#Release

##Theatrical

The film is scheduled to be released in 2023, with the team planning to release it in various languages, including Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, and Malayalam.

The film will be released in 3D and IMAX formats, with the team planning to release it in over 5,000 theaters across the world.

##Film festivals

The film is expected to premiere at various film festivals, including the Cannes Film Festival and the Toronto International Film Festival.

##Distribution

The film's distribution rights have been acquired by a major film studio, with the team planning to release it in various territories across the world.

##Pre-release business

The film's pre-release business has been estimated to be around ₹1,000 crore, making it one of the biggest pre-release deals in Indian cinema.

##Home media

The film's home media rights have been acquired by a major streaming platform, with the team planning to release it on DVD and Blu-ray formats.

#Reception

The film is expected to perform well at the box office, with the team predicting a worldwide gross of over ₹2,000 crore.

##Critical response

The film has received positive reviews from critics, with many praising its visual effects, action sequences, and performances.

#Future

The film's success is expected to lead to a franchise, with the team planning to release a series of sequels and spin-offs.

Damar Hamlin is an American football safety who currently plays for the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League (NFL). Born on March 24, 1998, in McKees Rocks, Pennsylvania, Hamlin rose to national prominence after a remarkable college career and a promising start to his professional career.

# Early life

Hamlin grew up in a tight-knit community in McKees Rocks, a small borough just outside of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. His parents, Mario and Nina Hamlin, instilled in him a strong work ethic and a passion for sports from an early age. Hamlin's older brother, Damarius, was also a talented athlete, and the two brothers would often engage in friendly competitions that helped shape Damar's competitive spirit.

Hamlin attended Central Catholic High School in Pittsburgh, where he excelled in multiple sports, including football, basketball, and track. As a standout athlete, he earned numerous accolades, including being named a First-Team All-State selection in football and a member of the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review's "Fab 22" team.

# College career

Hamlin played college football at the University of Pittsburgh, where he was a key contributor to the Panthers' defense. During his four-year tenure, he appeared in 46 games, recording 182 tackles, 21 passes defensed, and six interceptions. Hamlin's impressive collegiate career earned him multiple All-ACC honors and recognition as one of the top safeties in the conference.

## College statistics

* Games played: 46
* Tackles: 182
* Passes defensed: 21
* Interceptions: 6

# Professional career

The Buffalo Bills selected Hamlin in the sixth round (212th overall) of the 2021 NFL Draft. Despite being a late-round pick, Hamlin quickly established himself as a valuable member of the Bills' secondary.

## 2021 season

As a rookie, Hamlin played in 14 games, recording 30 tackles and two passes defensed. He saw significant playing time due to injuries to other defensive backs and proved to be a reliable contributor.

## 2022 season

### In-game collapse

On January 2, 2023, during a Monday Night Football game against the Cincinnati Bengals, Hamlin suffered a cardiac arrest on the field. The incident occurred in the first quarter, when Hamlin tackled Bengals wide receiver Tee Higgins, and subsequently collapsed. Medical personnel immediately responded, and Hamlin was administered CPR and an automated external defibrillator (AED) before being transported to the University of Cincinnati Medical Center.

### Recovery

Hamlin spent several days in the intensive care unit, where he underwent a series of tests and treatments. His condition slowly improved, and he was eventually transferred to a rehabilitation facility. In the weeks that followed, Hamlin made significant progress, and his doctors reported that he was on the road to a full recovery.

### Reactions

The incident sparked an outpouring of support from the NFL community, with players, coaches, and fans from across the league offering well-wishes and prayers for Hamlin's recovery. The Bills organization, in particular, rallied around their teammate, with players and staff members visiting him in the hospital and wearing "Pray for Damar" t-shirts during games.

### Awards

In recognition of his bravery and resilience, Hamlin was awarded the NFL's Art Rooney Award, which honors players who demonstrate outstanding sportsmanship and community service.

## 2023 season

Hamlin made a remarkable return to the field in 2023, playing in 10 games and recording 40 tackles and two interceptions. His comeback was an inspiration to fans and players alike, and he was named a Second-Team All-Pro by the Associated Press.

## 2024 season

As of the 2024 season, Hamlin remains a key member of the Bills' secondary, and his future in the NFL looks bright.

article:
History of County Durham

County Durham, a county in northeast England, has a rich and varied history spanning thousands of years. From its pre-Roman era to the present day, the county has played a significant role in shaping the course of English history. This article provides an overview of the major events, periods, and developments that have shaped the history of County Durham.

#Roman and pre-Roman

The earliest known human habitation in the area now known as County Durham dates back to the Mesolithic period, around 8000 BC. Archaeological evidence suggests that the region was inhabited by various tribes, including the Brigantes and the Votadini, before the Roman conquest of Britain in the 1st century AD. The Romans established a fort at Binchester, near modern-day Bishop Auckland, and a settlement at Escomb, which is now a small village.

#Anglo-Saxon

##Anglian Kingdom of Bernicia

Following the Roman withdrawal from Britain in the 5th century AD, the area now known as County Durham was settled by the Anglo-Saxons. The kingdom of Bernicia, which stretched from the Humber Estuary to the Firth of Forth, was established in the 6th century. Bernicia was eventually absorbed into the kingdom of Northumbria, which was a major power in Anglo-Saxon England.

##Kingdom of Northumbria

The kingdom of Northumbria, which was formed in the 7th century, played a significant role in the development of County Durham. The kingdom was a major center of learning and culture, and its capital, York, was an important hub of trade and commerce. Northumbria was eventually divided into two kingdoms, Bernicia and Deira, which were later reunited under a single ruler.

#City of Durham founded

The city of Durham was founded in 995 AD by monks from Lindisfarne, who were fleeing from Viking raids. The monks established a new monastery on a rocky outcrop overlooking the River Wear, and the city grew up around it. Durham became an important center of learning and pilgrimage, and its cathedral, which was built in the 11th century, is one of the finest examples of Norman architecture in England.

#Norman and Anglo-Norman

The Norman Conquest of England in 1066 had a profound impact on County Durham. The Normans introduced their own system of government, language, and culture, which gradually replaced the Anglo-Saxon way of life. The county was granted to the Bishop of Durham, who became one of the most powerful men in the north of England.

#County Palatine of Durham

The County Palatine of Durham was a unique entity that existed from the 12th to the 19th century. The county was governed by the Bishop of Durham, who had almost complete control over its administration, laws, and finances. The bishop was responsible for collecting taxes, maintaining law and order, and providing military forces in times of war.

##Early administration

The County Palatine of Durham was administered from the city of Durham, which was the seat of the bishop's power. The county was divided into several districts, each of which was governed by a local official known as a "steward." The stewards were responsible for collecting taxes, maintaining roads and bridges, and providing military forces in times of war.

##Boundaries, exclaves and population

The County Palatine of Durham had a complex system of boundaries, which included several exclaves and enclaves. The county was bounded by the River Tees to the south, the North Sea to the east, and the Scottish border to the north. The population of the county was largely rural, with many people living in small villages and hamlets.

##Survey

A survey of the county was conducted in the 13th century, which provided valuable information about its population, economy, and administration. The survey showed that the county was largely agricultural, with many people employed in farming and related industries.

##Palatinate

The Palatinate of Durham was a unique entity that existed from the 12th to the 19th century. The palatinate was governed by the Bishop of Durham, who had almost complete control over its administration, laws, and finances. The bishop was responsible for collecting taxes, maintaining law and order, and providing military forces in times of war.

##Wars

County Durham played a significant role in several wars throughout its history, including the Wars of the Roses, the English Civil War, and the Napoleonic Wars. The county was an important center of military recruitment, and many of its men fought in battles both at home and abroad.

##Parliamentary representation and secular powers

The County Palatine of Durham was represented in Parliament by two members, who were elected by the freeholders of the county. The bishop of Durham also had a seat in the House of Lords, which gave him a significant voice in national affairs. The secular powers of the bishop were gradually eroded over the centuries, and the county eventually became subject to the same laws and administration as the rest of England.

#Later government

The County Palatine of Durham was abolished in the 19th century, and the county became subject to the same laws and administration as the rest of England. The county council was established in 1889, which provided a new system of local government. The county council was responsible for providing a range of services, including education, healthcare, and highways.

#Eighteenth century

The 18th century was a time of significant change and development in County Durham. The county became an important center of industry, with many coal mines and textile mills being established. The population of the county grew rapidly, and many new towns and villages were built to accommodate the growing number of people.

#Nineteenth century

The 19th century was a time of rapid industrialization and urbanization in County Durham. The county became one of the most important centers of industry in England, with many coal mines, ironworks, and textile mills being established. The population of the county grew rapidly, and many new towns and villages were built to accommodate the growing number of people.

#Twentieth century

The 20th century was a time of significant change and development in County Durham. The county played a significant role in both World War I and World War II, and many of its men fought in battles both at home and abroad. 2022 Stanley Cup playoffs

The 2022 Stanley Cup playoffs was the playoff tournament of the National Hockey League (NHL) for the 2021-22 season. The playoffs began on May 2, 2022, and concluded on June 26, 2022, with the Colorado Avalanche winning their third Stanley Cup in franchise history, defeating the Tampa Bay Lightning in the Stanley Cup Finals.

# Playoff seeds

The top eight teams from each conference, based on points percentage, qualified for the playoffs. The top three teams from each division, plus two wild-card teams from each conference, made up the playoff field.

## Eastern Conference

### Atlantic Division

### Metropolitan Division

The Florida Panthers, winners of the Atlantic Division, took on the Washington Capitals, the second wild-card team from the Eastern Conference. The Panthers won the series 4-2, with captain Aleksander Barkov leading the team with 5 points.

The Toronto Maple Leafs, second place in the Atlantic Division, faced off against the Tampa Bay Lightning, the third-place team in the division. The Lightning won the series 4-3, with goalie Andrei Vasilevskiy making 53 saves in the decisive Game 7.

### (M1) Carolina Hurricanes vs. (WC1) Boston Bruins

The Carolina Hurricanes, winners of the Metropolitan Division, took on the Boston Bruins, the first wild-card team from the Eastern Conference. The Hurricanes won the series 4-3, with forward Martin Necas scoring 3 goals in the series.

The New York Rangers, second place in the Metropolitan Division, faced off against the Pittsburgh Penguins, the third-place team in the division. The Rangers won the series 4-3, with goalie Igor Shesterkin making 79 saves in the decisive Game 7.

### (P2) Edmonton Oilers vs. (P3) Los Angeles Kings

The Edmonton Oilers, second place in the Pacific Division, faced off against the Los Angeles Kings, the third-place team in the division. The Oilers won the series 4-3, with forward Connor McDavid scoring 3 goals in the series.
